Derek! You forgot that important science axiom - correlation is not causation. If a greater proportion of people who have written down their resolutions have been successful at maintaining them for a year, that doesn't mean that writing down their resolutions played any part in their success. They might have already been more organized and more cognizant of their own needs for success, which prompted them to write their resolutions down and which independently helped them to succeed. Writing down one's resolutions will not imbue someone with these qualities.

Last year I realized I have a root issue with obligation. I can certainly do things, but when I feel like I HAVE to do them (with no choice) i loose motivation and shut down. So, I made a small dry erase board (no larger than a clip board) and employed micro goals.

I set as many micro goals as I want (that can be completed in 5 mins or less) and fill the board with them. At first I mixed these with super basic things like “brush teeth”. That seems silly to write down, but it got me into the habit of remembering to write it down first, and taught me the satisfaction of being able to wipe an item off the list.

If I run out of space, I don’t add anything until I take something else off. This keeps me from feeling overwhelmed with an ever-growing list. And it motivates me to get some of the tougher ones done because I’m eager to make room for more. Also, rather than feeling obligated to do some chore, I’m instead choosing from a list. It all has to be done anyway so no choice is wasted time.

I keep my hopes and dreams in a journal, and when I’ve done enough micro goals to reach a milestone, I record the progress in the journal.

I’ve been doing this since January and I feel so much more productive. I no longer have those days where I feel like “ I’ve been working all day and all I’ve done is two things.”

Coming back to this video 7 months later and in that time I’ve lost 40 pounds, committed to working out regularly, got a new job that’s way better than my old one and really started taking my life seriously for the first time. Idk what it was that clicked in my brain this year, I really can’t say for sure how much this video had to do with it but I will say that the strategy I used was pretty much exactly what you laid out here. Small incremental changes week after week that slowly add up over time. It’s crazy how much better my life is now compared to how it was when this video came out. I have my own place, an investment portfolio and I’m finally on track to actually get sober by slowly eliminating all the drugs and unhealthy food I’ve been addicted to for decades. I’m like a completely different person. This time last year I was 185 lbs, ate fast food multiple times a week and took as much as 15 grams of phenibut a day along with the suboxone I used to get off heroin. As I type this I’m completely off suboxone and down to 2 grams a day of phenibut. I don’t eat fast food at all and just prior to watching this I ran an 11 minute mile. And if that doesn’t sound impressive just know that I haven’t tried to run in literally years and keeping a steady pace of 5.5mph for an entire mile is a huge accomplishment for me especially as it followed a workout that included 100 pull ups, 200 push ups and 300 squats.

Anyway sorry I’m totally rambling here it’s just that this video reminded me of how far I’ve come since you uploaded it and I’m really stoked on all my progress. One day at a time, taking small steps in the right direction is the way to go. Two years ago I was addicted to heroin and had nothing going for me so if I can do it anyone can.

I think motivation and resolutions are BS. If you REALLY want to do something, you just end up doing it. Because it's what you want. Motivation, discipline, tricks and all that are for things you don't really want to do. Oh, you might "want" to do them because you think they're things you should do, but you don't truly want to—otherwise you'd already be doing them. So resolutions fail because we try to get ourselves to do things we don't really want to do. Resolutions tend to be self-critical, self-denying, self-flagellating, rather than being commitments to do more of the things we enjoy and less of the things we don't.

The most common resolutions revolve around exercise and fitness, and while vague goals are certainly a big part of why they quit, a bigger issue is unrealistic expectations. For example, the fitness industry has convinced people that they need to exercise to lose weight. As a lifelong fitness nut I can tell you that this is completely untrue. Numerous studies have shown that exercise is almost completely ineffectual for losing weight. So of course people quit after a couple of months. Why would anyone continue to do something that's uncomfortable, inconvenient, and doesn't work? This isn't laziness. It's logic. When setting any goal, it's important to check your assumptions at the door and do some research. Sometimes that means some real digging. People who go to the gym daily tend to have a healthy body weight, but it doesn't follow from this that going to the gym is the reason they are thin. With a little thought it's obvious that diet is also a factor, and some research from that point will show that when it comes to weight loss, diet is by far the most influential factor. This doesn't mean you shouldn't exercise, though, just that exercising for weight loss is doomed to fail.

Unfortunately, most of the 'advice' in this video goes against what the research says works.

Be specific? Nope, the research suggests being vague is actually more effective because it allows flexibility.
Write down your resolution? Nope, the research suggests that telling people your goals makes it less likely that you will achieve them.
Make your resolutions small and consistently achievable? Kinda, the research suggests that small goals can be helpful, but they can also lead to a feeling of despair after 'succeeding' at your goal only to find that it didn't actually achieve much.
You don't have to be productive every minute of every day. Often it's productive psychologically and emotionally to simply enjoy the moment.

Great video as usual! I have one comment on the third part: backup distractions also need to be taken into account! If you feel safe because you have improved your environment so as to get rid your typical distractions - e.g. you can no longer browse socials or read the news - chances are you will lower your guard and those distractions will come back in another form, or new distractions will sneak up on you. A rather silly example: you feel you're saving time by staying away from socials and newspapers, hence you think you can treat yourself to a couple minesweeper games, and before you know it, you end up wasting as much time as you used to. The solution to this in my opinion: improving your environment by ALSO allowing yourself some small, carefully planned treats - such as 1-2 minesweeper games MAX as a reward for the hard work - such that your mind doesn't really miss the distractions.

Watched this video when it came out, and I thought about it. Don't have Simone's calendar, but I do have a calendar on my computer and I decided to keep track of progress there. I pre-set notes on the calendar and make them yellow, 3 for each day. Then at the end of the day I set each note either green or red. If I have a red mark I don't worry about it and move on.

I decided I would change the way I EAT, change the way I MOVE, and change the way I SLEEP.

EAT Eat anything I want, but only at certain times. Monday: nothing. Tuesday: vegetarian. Wednesday: nothing. Thursday: vegetarian. Friday: normal. Saturday: normal. Sunday: high meat. So far I'm 100% compliant. I weigh myself when I first wake up. Wednesday the 1st I weighed 187.0 pounds. Monday the 6th I weighed 186.4 pounds. And Monday the 13th I weighed 182.8 pounds. It's Monday the 13th now. When the hunger pangs hit I drink water. I drink a lot of water.

MOVE Walk 20 minutes per day. I missed only 1 day. I was up in the attic "duckwalking" across the trusses, and by the end of the day I was exhausted. Still, a red mark is a red mark. Someday I'll add other exercise, but for now I walk. Hmmm, reminds me of this song: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dKF8IzBmp74

SLEEP Get to bed by midnight. With all that's been happening (my house guests show up at 2:00am and then stay up late every night) I'm 6 red and 6 green so far. However it's been getting easier to fall asleep when I do get to bed. And I've started getting up between 7:00am and 8:00am without an alarm. Once I settle into this I might dial the time back to 11:00pm, and maybe earlier.

My resolution is quitting, that is quitting with snus (tobacco product that is very popular in Norway and Sweden in particular), although it should be noted that I started stepping down already right before christmas eve and it should be noted that I also quit once before but due to temptations (yes i had a weak moment) and being surrounded by users of the stuff pretty much every day, i fell back into bad habits. I do however hope that I have learned my lesson though, and that I can get into a new (temporary) habit of biting into gum whenever i feel tempted instead.

My other resolution i imagine is actually a bit harder, cut back on sodas, sugars and meat and eat more vegetarian. The first part is the hard part, but it ties into the second part because eating healthy actually makes us picky eaters strangely enough. If we eat healthier, then our body rewards us by telling us that this is good for us just like it tells us that junk-food and all the other stuff tastes great if we have been eating that for a prolonged period. I do however have a small love for vegetarian already so it is more about taking the time to prepare it, learning to get into habits of cooking it and above all else, making something that i find palatable (i somehow have never managed that with vegetarian meals so far). I have gotten a few books that combines foods in ways that are supposed to be a tasty treat but at the same time, healthy.

As far as exercise goes, not a plan for this years resolutions, hopefully a better living overall will give me an energy boosts so that i will get of my bony ass (cause i am a very thin guy overall) and get into better shape.

But for those thinking this is too much and too big goals, not to worry, I have a plan. My first goal is quitting the tobacco, and I won't even consider starting the rest until I am at least a month clean of that. Only then do I know that I can control the urge to not buy the crap later on, so baby steps.

Other than that, happy new year to all, good luck with your resolutions and best of wishes from Norway ;)

Couldn't agree more with the 1% improvement rule. I've realized this one instinctively when I wanted to start improving my health. I knew from previous experience that I wouldn't spend an hour a day exercising, but I stumbled on the 7-minutes workout which was backed by actual scientific evidence. It ended up being my starting point. 7 minutes is almost nothing in a day, and that workout can be done with no equipment, no gym membership. I've integrated it right before taking my morning shower, and it slowly grew to 20 minutes over the last 8 months. I've added resistance bands to increase tension and have seen some significant gains. Resistance bands are great because they're in the same minimal philosophy. A set of 5 bands fits in a lunch box and can replace an entire gym, so there really is no reason to skip the workout. I've found myself working out even when I'm in a bad mood or sick, only because there's basically so little barrier it gets really hard to procrastinate.

My wider, overall goal is to become a healthier person this year.

To split this down into smaller tasks, which i can do everyday.

Next is to get at least a few minutes of excersize every day. (Push ups, sit ups, squats, running)

I will also be eating some fresh fruit every day, such as oranges, apples, graprfruit, bananas.

While uninstalling social media is fantastic, and something I have sustained for the last few years, I have come to realize that it is a bit superficial. My mind has just come up with other better distractions now. The app isn't making you waste time, there is something inside you that finds the app a convenient thing to do, probably something that is uncomfortable with the current moment and wants to "escape" in some way.
So, my new year resolution is to examine my own drives and motivations as closely as possible, by asking myself "Why am I doing this?" and "Is it actually having the effect I intended?" and listening deeply for the answers, as often as possible.
I will be saying goodbye to my anxiety and depression , ( I have made much progress) and enroll for my Ph.D in Physics 😃. And in due time , I will become a scientist ☺️🙂

While deleting social media apps might seem like a good idea to restrict your time spent and therefore wasted on those apps, I believe strengthening your willpower instead is the better approach. While the outcome might be the same, not wanting to use social media or knowing that it is a waste of time and hence not doing it is far better than not doing it because of restricting yourself but still wanting to do it. This approach will be harder to manage but once your willpower is strong enough to resist the urge to go on Instagram for example, falling back into old habits is far less likely.

I do not make New Year's Resolutions, I make Goals for the New Year. Many people feel that if they break the resolution, it is over and they might as well wait until next year.

If you look at the definition of a "resolution" it basically boils down to “a formal expression of opinion, will, or intent voted by an official body or assembled group”. It is just a decision or an expression, there is no action.

Look up "goal" and you get “the end toward which effort is directed”. A goal requires action (effort) and a time period in which to do it.

This is why I make goals for the new year. I define an end state that requires action and a time in which to accomplish it. It is something to continue to strive for.

Here's an anecdotal counter point to the specific goals. For me personally, if I have a goal such as writing in a diary daily; the first time I miss a day my motivation drops through the floor and I'll be less likely to continue because I feel like I failed. Whereas having vague goals such as losing weight is easily obtainable because any weight lost is a victory instead of shooting for the stars and falling short.


P.S. I hope you have a great new year.

At 1:20: It’s the odometer effect. I get a kick out of images of odometers rolling over, especially in the 240K range (miles).

At 1:58: I am just guessing that the desire for quick gratification works against resolutions sticking. But it’s the resolution itself that ought to be gratifying, which is why things that ought to be good for you better taste good too.

Interestingly I've came to this atomic approach of making small steps toward a goal, essentialy based of my life so far.
I mean, big goals were just out of reach and I was barelly making any progress towards them, and at a point in life I've read a sentence in a book, something like : " if you are waiting for a moment when everything absolutely everything is set - you'll never even begin " .
Since then I have the attitude of f#ck it - life is quite short to waste it in daily routines, complaints about small superficial irrelevant things and in surroundings where you don't feel whole.

I think that there's a fair amount of people in developed parts of world who realisticaly have a lot, but feel a kind of a hole, an incompletness which they try to barry in layers of stuff they buy or watch or by doing routine or using instagram/fb etc, just as long as they don't have to be alone with their thoughts.
There's a limit to how much we can absorb and how much awake, attentive hours we have every day.
;) let's use them to the forces of good

With all due respect Derek, I don't think "deleting social media apps" is the best way to go about solving the problem of spending too much time on those apps. Instagram and Twitter can be distracting, I understand that but they are also the best way for me to stay connected with educators like you. Things that you like, share and repost help me stay updated on what's going on in the scientific community. There are apps out there that will monitor the amount of time you're spending on those social media and help you restrict it to a specific time. Deleting Instagram and Twitter from your phone doesn't necessarily solve your problem of getting distracted.

In my opinion this does not really bring a solution to quiting a resolution. I think its about having a certain mindset, being able to recognize your abilities, where as big results require big changes, requires big motivation. You can break it down, but do not act like you live twice. You are wasting an entire year and you should do something a little big bigger, because you are great. You are a human being, you are capable of things that you do not know of. Recognize your abilities, think every day of what your goal is, and right at the moment where you are sinking, just go back to this comment, its true. You’ll sink, you’ll sink even deeper, and there is where it gets hard. You have to come back up, and if you’re up, when you climb that last rock, that’s when you have achieved an actual resolution. I do think Simones calendar is one of the most helpful things out there, but also a normal $5 calendar will do the trick. Just spend 25 seconds every day on what you’re achieving.

Goodluck. See you next year. :)

At least, that's the condensed version. I like "goals" more than "resolutions." A goal is something I can measure and feel some sort of success on. I've always had a mental block around the idea of a "resolution," that I have to be 100% perfect and not miss a single day or else it's worthless and not worth trying. Maybe it's just psychological, but goals I've always felt I can adjust.

1. Lose weight & eat healthy:
1.1. I will commit to seeing a personal trainer by the end of January and meet with them at least 3 times by the beginning of March.
1.2. I will commit to seeing a dietitian/nutritionist by the end of January. I genuinely do not know how to eat healthy, especially in a way that is sustainable and easy as a college student.
1.3. I will aim to lose an average of 1lb/week. At my current weight and fitness level, this should be quite sustainable for at least a few months. An important measure is that I want to lose at least 20lbs by June.
2. Get good grades
2.1. I commit to not missing more than 3 sessions of any of my classes for the semester.
2.2. I commit to spending time working on schoolwork every day (I still need to figure this one out!).
2.3. I aim to get no less than a C on any test; if I do, then I will reevaluate how I study/prepare.
2.4. I will reevaluate at midterms to see how I am progressing.
3. I will be more social.
3.1. I will join a club by the end of January and commit to at least three meetings. After that, I will add more goals; at the moment, I have so few social interactions that I don't even know where to start.

Here are my notes from this video.

A common Misconception is that you need to go big. You overcommit to your goals and you don't stick to them. Create Small targets and hit them consistently.

In book atomic habits there is an idea that if you can get one percent better everyday, it'll be the minimum amount of effort but overtime the effects will compound, like compound interest. 

2 minute rule: Pick something you can do in two minutes. and then you can't say you don't have time for it.

Write at least one word into your daily planner everyday.

Another problem is that New year resolutions are too vague (lose weight, excercise more, eat better). Be specific  and detailed. 

Track your progress visually, Everyday of the year.

Third problem is people think it's that it's about having more willpower, motivation and resisting to temptations. Relying on willpower is not an effective strategy, as willpower is finite resource, people who have more self control actually have to exercise their willpower less by changing their environment.

Delete social media apps from your phone, At least block any kind of distraction, it takes 20 to 25 minutes to get back to what you were doing if you were distracted. By blocking apps, websites you don't have to exercise your willpower to not open these apps, websites etc, and you can use your willpower to do productive things. WIN WIN.
I have a question. If you are removing your social media apps from your phone, are you going to keep them elsewhere - like a tablet?

I want to get a gaming computer, which would make me even more sedentary, so my resolution is that I'm not allowed to consume entertainment (games, shows, internet) unless I've done at least 10 minutes of working out in the past two days. This way, I force myself to work out before I veg out at least every other day. And I'm hoping to ramp up the workout time to 30 minutes. If I can keep this up for several months, I'll get the gaming computer in the fall, maybe for a back-to-school sale. I've tried to start workout habits before and failed, but I think designing it in a way where I "parent myself" and try to preempt bad habits is a better approach. I usually ignore new year's resolutions because my geeky side sees the new year as an arbitrary time, but if research shows it's helpful, I have nothing to lose by trying it.

People often mistake motivation for discipline. Those are two entirely separate things. You feel motivated to do something new for the New Year, but you must know discipline in order to sustain. "Will power is a finite resource" this isn't really considered true anymore. This myth is based on a 1990 study by Baumiester which has been disputed by multiple large sample size recent studies. A meta study by Evan Carter of 200 ego depletion studies concluded that most positive claims were a result of publication bias. Interestingly, the only time positive results were shown was in the case when participants in studies were told of ego depletion before the test, essentially making it so that believing in ego depletion was a self fulfill prophecy.

1. Start exercising again. My new years resolution is to get safe and easily accessible fresh water to my community. Last year my resolution was to stop drinking as much soda and high-glucose juices and I've almost entirely switched to water. However, in my community we need to get water shipped in. The local water supply is tainted by oil sands companies both dumping into ground reserves, which inevitably leak into our supply, as well as through the massive plumes of steam which carry dangerous chemicals through the sky, and condense back into water droplets which fall in our lakes and rivers. Changing the entire economy for northern Alberta isn't really an option, so I plan on fulfilling a lot of small goals to help both me and my community get a safer and more accessible fresh water supply.

I'm so glad you brought up the decade thing. What I notice though when most people say the end of the decade, they do not make a distinction between simply the 2010s and the chronological 202nd decade, and it seems like many don't know that there is a distinction at all. Decades, centuries, and millennia all start the same way, ending with a 1, ie 2001 being the start of the 201st decade, 21st century, and 3rd millennium. The 10 year blocks of 10s, 20s, 30s, and so on are simply arbitrary but convenient markers, but we could just as easily label "the" decade as 2015 to 2024 or anywhere else, or even just measure blocks in years of 5, or lustra. What really bothers me the most about these blocks of 10s, 20s, 30s, etc is that if you go all the way back in the calendar to the first 10s, the "decade" before it only has 9 years. It's like we started counting with a fraction instead of an integer and it doesn't sit right with me. It just shits all over the first decade. I think people just like it when a 9 flips to a 0 like in a car's mileage counter. There's nothing sexy or exciting about a 0 flipping to a 1. The only logical thing to do now is to celebrate both ends of "the" decade. Pizza party for the start of the 2020s, and a pizza party in 2021 for the start of the 203rd decade.

I just want to add that my thinking for 2021 being the first year of the decade is based on how we count. When we count other things, 1 is the first one, and 10 is the last one, in every string of numbers divided into groups of 10.

I have yet to encounter anyone who starts counting at 0 and ends with 9.

New years resolutions fail because they go against your nature. Like exercising. It's boring and painful. You just want the result: become more attractive to have sex with beautiful people. You can change the success rate by 3 ways: either make the process more enjoyable (e.g. listen to a good podcast or audiobook during the exercise, or bring friends to exercise with you) or during the pain constantly remind yourself of the pleasure you'll get (e.g. while doing exercises, constantly visualize you getting fitter and getting more looks from the beautiful people at the gym and taking them home and having sex with them) or by changing your emotional pathways (e.g. instead of focusing on how delicious a hamburger would be to eat, focus on how that'll clog your heart, and you'll feel a sudden heart attack with a lot of pain, and won't be able to enjoy other things that you like)

If I could give one small piece of feedback from this video which might help you in all your public speaking, be it on youtube/in person etc.You SHOULD NOT tell people what they SHOULD do. Or at least, when you do using the word 'should' it opinionizes it and makes the plea less effective. Instead when trying to make a 'should' statement, state the benefits first and then highlight the fact that it would be beneficial to listen to you.


I'm thinking mostly of the line 'you SHOULD write your resolutions in the comments', and my immediate reaction honestly was 'NO!' Another way you could have said that was 'One way of doing that is writing in the comments below, you can write in o a piece of paper at home or on your phone'...that way you're less telling people what to do with the word should, and more giving them options on how to better themselves.

As someone who has kept a 'dairy' from age 17 to 49 here are some observations. First, don't get a book which has all the days in it. It only ends up emphasising the days you miss. It also limits you when you want to write more. Use a notebook. Second, don't commit to writing a word a day, commit to using it to document your achievements, your plans and your failures. Don't frame it in a way where failing to write will only make you feel guilty. Use it as a tool for self reflection and planning. Finally, carry it with your everywhere. Get into the habit of writing it in as a discussion with yourself. I'm on book 108. I have changed two laws in New Zealand through persistence, community and the practice of deliberate reflection and planning through writing.

So anyone reading this. The resolution is in the habit. Like he said we put the task on a pedestal and make it monumental. I have learned that if I just do one thing I can usually find myself doing a bit more. For instance if my resolution is to exercise more then just start with one pushup, just one situp. Or pick up something heavy just one time. Do that everyday. If you can't do that everyday then you either have a serious medical condition or you are lying to yourself. As you do them you will find yourself saying hey lets try one or two more. So the idea is that you are doing the task everyday and trying to form the habit. It will take you about 30 days or slightly less to form the habit so once you form the habit you don't have to con yourself into doing something you don't want because the repetition is already there.  We don't want to exercise in the beginning because its tough, but very quickly it gets pretty easy to do. So just start with one. Your mind will say, "Working out for 30 minutes and working up a sweat, hell no; but doing one pushup, situp, or pullup, yeah I can do that. I can spare the time and the energy to do just ONE". That's all it takes. Of course you won't make much progress doing just one but I find that starting is the hardest part. Once you start its easy to keep momentum going. Now here is the part that will happen to everyone. YOU WILL FAIL. Yes thats right no matter if you are superman or batman, you are going to fail. You are going to miss a workout day. Does that mean you stop and say oh well, better luck next year? NOPE. You start again the next day, and you keep going till the habit finally forms. If you are like and your super power is finding a way to procrastinate no matter what with fake busy work then it's time to get some help and get someone to hold you accountable. That was the only way for me was to hire someone that called me and followed up and held me accountable. Just because you start eating mountains of cake and stop working out in Februrary for Easter or whatever does not mean you stop working out and continue eating cake for the rest of the year. You pick yourself back up and keep going.

The advice you give for keeping new year's resolutions is very similar to strategies taught in drug rehab, addiction counseling, and moral reconation therapy. I've done all of those and each one emphasized having reasonable and attainable goals, creating a plan that's broken down to small steps that aren't too daunting, setting reasonable time frames, and writing down and reviewing progress. Trying to do too much too fast tends to overwhelm and can lead to feelings of hopelessness or failure and a regression back to the familiar bad habits we hope to change.

Another similar point is something that anyone who has ever gone to an AA/NA meeting or addiction counseling will be familiar with. The best way to avoid slipping back into bad habits is to minimize or eliminate situations that will confront you with easy access or the option to indulge. An anecdote from a former addiction counselor that stuck with me was that she started taking a different route on her commute to avoid driving past any stores that carried alcohol so that she was less tempted and didn't have to test her willpower as much.

To set realistic resolution goals dont say "Do ___ every day every (or week, or month)" but instead say "Do _____ on average X# of times each day (or week or month)". That way when something comes up you didnt fail and you can make it up another time.
For instance in 2018 my goal was to "go to a yoga class on average once a week." I would try to go twice a week but some weeks I wouldn't be able to make it to even one class. At the end of the year my average was 1.2 classes per week.
For 2019 my goal was to "read on average one book a month." The year started off slow and I was lagging behind in Jan, Feb, and March but I finished 13 and am 3/4 of the way through the 14th book.

So here are the takeaways:

1. Set specific goals (do you know S.M.A.R.T. Goal? Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Realistic, Time-bound)
2. Write down your goals
3. Track your progress in a visual way (don’t rely on memory)
4. Restructure your environment and do not rely on will power (e.g. if you want to reduce social media hours, delete the app!)

Ah, yes, the old argument about when a century or decade begins. What I have done is to look at the numbering system for addresses in many cities in the USA. The first block has numbers from 1 to 99 (only 99 possibilities) but the second block has 100-199 (100 possibilities). All succeeding blocks also have 100 possibilities. We somehow accept that as OK but rebel against the eccentricity of the first decade/century of the Julian and Gregorian calendars. We need to chill.

The year 2020 is still not part of the 2020s. Because when the calendar says 2020, it does not mean that many years have passed. Even at July 2020 for example, you are only half way through the year 2020, so at that point it is technically only 2019.5. The way in which we use whole numbers to denote years is not as a quantity, but as a noun, as a result the number we give to each year can be misleading, in addition to being incorrect.

That's where I will end my pedantic rant.

In iOS, 
Settings > General > Accessibility > Display Accommodations > Color Filters > On > Select "Grayscale".

Go back to: Settings > General > Accessibility > Accessibility Shortcut > click "Color Filters"

This allows you to triple-click the home button to cycle through a normal color and a black and white screen. Switch to a black and white screen when you shouldn't be looking at your phone to remind yourself to not "mindlessly" check Instagram.

I started making monthly goals to keep on track with my new year's resolutions. I write them all down and keep them pinned to the top of my notes app so that I keep my goals in mind! Breaking bigger goals down into small, easier to accomplish steps really helps to keep me on track. I've found since I've done this I don't have that moment of looking back at my big picture goals late in the year realizing I've missed too many important "deadlines" for the steps along the way. Two years ago I set a goal to get back to a weight that was healthy for my body. I lost 50 pounds and was told by my doctor (for the first time ever) that I am at a healthy weight! This past year I've managed to keep that healthy weight through setting reasonable goals that are broken down into small steps! I hope all of you accomplish your goals and remember that it is never too late to make steps to improve yourself!

I am so tired of this "there was no year zero" stuff. Of course there was a year zero; it was right before the year 1. Just because some 6th Century person didn't know how zero worked, there is no reason we have to propagate that sort of ignorance. After all, we no longer believe in phlogiston or the four humors. We fix our mistakes. There's no reason not to fix that one, either.

But, you say, what about the jump from 1 BC to 1 AD? What you need to realize is that there are 2 complete OVERLAPPING number lines in play here: the AD number line that points to the future and the BC number line that points to the past. We can darn well switch from one to the other if we like. And we can do so wherever we like, including between 2 BC and 0 AD. But that 0 AD is there regardless. And then decades and millennia make sense again.

The idea is sound but I disagree with the "methodology"...

IMHO forcing, cornering or restricting yourself into doing something especially via "external" means is essentially shifting blame to that tool resulting in the "if I slip it's the tool at blame and not me" excuse...


I prefer to structure my rhythm in such a way that I want and do what I need to do -- who needs a gym when you can explore your town/city and walk/run home every day... instead of fighting yourself over what to consume, try to distinguish between your body saying what you need and "tasty treats" and connect your food cycle to your activity cycle (as an example, I eat once a day, and what I eat almost exclusively depends on what feels correct now and would feel good in the next hours, my activity and energy consumption)...

...fighting oneself and shifting responsibility to tools/apps is not constructive and simply makes the problem more complex to deal with.

But I just can't pretend that this is the end of the decade, and I don't understand how most people can make the compromise that this belief is "psychologically" correct. It's a math problem, not psychology or philosophy. In math there's only right and wrong, there's no "technically" correct.

Anyway, aside from that aside I really enjoyed this video. The strategy of having clearly defined, written goals, and making small, steady improvements toward them while tracking your progress seems like a good one. I think I my resolutions fail because I never write any of them down and don't track my progress - so either I stop improving or I underestimate how much improvement I've actually made - which leads to despair and dropping the whole project until next year. It sounds like regular, written down tracking could short-circuit this process.

Do we all really think that this subject is that fascinating? Because it isn’t. I don’t care for the thousand various theories unto why humans procrastinate or focus so heavily on specifically holiday themed, New Years, resolutions.

It’s dull. It’s been repeated every year for decades (as long as my lifelong memory at least) and by so, so many people.

Why are we still on this. Why. Why. Why?!

Anecdotal evidence, but my 2019 resolutions worked out precisely because they were written as SMART goals - I wanted to get to 100k followers on Instagram by the end of the year. I had a target for each day, first day of the year 101 new followers, second day 102, third 103 and so on. I printed a calendar with the targets and for every day I marked how many I actually gained. Marking all the days where I failed to reach the target was actually very motivating - sometimes I would just put more work into it, sometimes I would rethink the strategy completely. However, once I reached the goal I had no follow-up, so I just stopped.

1. The idea that you need to go big is ultimately unsustainable. Instead make realistic goals and know that they will compound and pay off over time.
2. Making too vague of a goal means it’s difficult to tell if you’re making progress, so write down your goals and be specific. Also write in a daily planner, even if you write very little, continuing this daily is worth it when you do feel like writing a lot.
3. Willpower alone is not reliable, it’s more scarce of a resource than people realize. Reserve your limited willpower by removing distractions like social media that you might expend willpower trying to keep away from.

I’m sure the gyms know the crowd is going to fizzle out after a couple weeks. The make this a vital part of their marketing campaign. A lot of industries flourish over blind rituals. In 2019 I was unemployed for 11 of the 12 months in that year. So my new years resolution is to get a job, plain and simple. I don't have any habits that need controlling, I will admit that I am out of shape but trying to start an exercise routine is not something that you can do when you have no routine at all. Since employment is the most important aspect of your life, the routine starts with that. Everything else then follows.

And for anyone who might be wondering why I have been unemployed for the last 11 months, it isn't from lack of trying, although in the first 3 months I did spend too much time on Facebook and binge watching You Tube. That was a pretty hard habit to kick, but I was fired right at the beginning of the year from a job I thought was my dream job, working at a radio station. I had volunteered for that station for 7 years before I got that job, and I felt like they really the me under the bus. I fell into a hole of depression so deep, that psychologists are using me as a case study because I have not tried to kill myself. Ok I made up the last part, but that is how I cope with my depression, by using an emotion that is stronger than it to beat it, whether it be humor, or anger, whatever.

Btw if anyone was wondering what my one month of employment was for this year, I worked at a deli. It was not my life's gosl but it was my only source of income, and I tried my best to keep it. The job I had at the radio station, I wss program manager. My best profession was being a mechanic, I have 10 years experience. Employers are more prone to hire a rookie fresh or of school so they can pay them minimum wage instead of an experienced technician. So for me to get a job, I am going to have to completely lower my expectations, or something, like working at McDonald's.

O: Give my dog the best dog experience he can have
KR: Walk the dog at least 3 times a week

O: Start my journey for being rich
KR: Save $12000 by the end of the year


The good thing with with is I can have dreamlike objectives, to keep me motivate on why I'm doing these things and at the same time by having key results which are specific, mesurable, achieavable and time-bounded I get a real sense of progress. Good thing is I can keep the same objectives from year to year and just work on updating the key results.

Rule 1 of economics: the easier it is to do something, the more likely it is that people will do it. Make your resolutions as easy to follow as possible.

So, I participate in the NaNoWriMo every year (National Novel Writing Month) and I can only agree with you on every point. Holding resolutions isn't a race, it's a marathon, a commitment to yourself. For example, in my first year of doing the NaNo, I found that writing 1667 words a day (for 50k words in 30 days) was extremely harsh but the excitement of the event helped me get to the goal. By the middle of the month, the excitement had waned and I found it difficult to keep writing. It was only by telling myself to get at least half of the day down that I kept myself going. And wouldn't you know it, most days, I was hitting close to the goal (80%-110%) without even searching for it because I had gotten myself to sit down and write a reachable goal. And on the days where I knocked nearly double the goal at once? Those felt great, but I didn't let it explode as "This is what I can do every day."

The real secret to achieving goals? Forget that a calendar even exists. There is no notion of some periodic repeating cycle of time. That is just a human construct. So whatever you want to achieve, give it all you got, even if it takes years to achieve.

1:23 January 1st, 2020 is unquestionably the first day of the 2020s. January 1st, 2021 is the first day of the 203rd decade A.D./C.E.. It’s a wording thing. For example, January 1st, 1900 was the first day of the 1900s, but January 1st, 1901 was the first day of the 20th century. Because 99/100 years in both the 1900s and the 20th century are the same, we use the terms 1900s and 20th century interchangeably, but they aren’t exactly the same.

So my first goal is to start training. I have been fysically active in the past three years but not so much this last year. So I have set a goal, and that is to walk 50 kilometres each week, which gives me allot of good items in Pokemon go! And I will start riding my bike again in the spring of 2020, and my goal for total distance riding my bike is 250 kilometres. This might be considered a weak goal by the few skilled athletics reading, but I might extend it.

My second goal in 2020, might be to learn more stuff that I already don't know. For example I recently started to learn how to make a website, and I think I will make a blog, if I can complete learning about it.

Now my third goal of 2020 is to be more active, in the form of going more on camping trips and mountain hikes. The reason why I want to do this is because I think I'm missing out on a loot, and I do live in Norway, which I would call a heaven for travellers, so I want to explore my country more!

My fourth goal, is to be more politically active in my commune. I can be hard for a foreigner to understand the political system where I live, but I will try to explain it in short terms. My country is divided in regions which there is 5 of, I live in one of those regions which is called Viken. There is multiple communes in each regions, where the commune decides what will happen most of the time, and the region can also be in charge of what will happen inside a commune, but when the region involves itself it's usually to build a road or something else that will have an effect for the whole region. The commune is controllrd by many people from different parties. But there happens to be a youth group of each party, which is responsible for getting information about what the commune can do better and stuff like that. And I want to join one of those youth parties and learn more about my commune!


So this is the end so far atleast, but for those who read my whole comment, I just want to wish for the best and that you can forfill your goals😁

For 2019 my resolution was to not drink any alcohol anymore. I rarely drank any alcohol before, but beeing out with friends it always took decision-energy and arguments to decide if I'm going to drink a beer or not or even a second beer. So just deciding not to drink anything beforehand was just a way to make it easier. Friends stopped trying to get me to drink because they figured it was pointless since I never gave in anymore. I thinm on like 3-5 events throughout the year I would've liked to have a beer or a cocktail because it would've fit the atmosphere, but it wasn't really a big sacrifice. The reason I don't want to drink any alcohol anymore is simply to have more energy because I found that even after a few beers the next day I would feel a little bit more tired.

For 2020 I will of course continue this no alcohol resolution but together with my girlfriend we decided to add another thing that we feel will give us more enegry and also a better conscience. We both love eating meat and we don't want to completely stop eating it, but we are also convinced that the meat industry is hurting our planet ecologically, that eating too much and too low quality meat is not good for ourselves and many more arguments. This is why we made the decision to not buy any non-vegetarian product at the supermarket in 2020. Also we will not eat any non-vegetarian fast food. The only way we will eat meat is if we buy high quality, locally produced meat from a farm or when we eat at a good restaurant or are invited to someone else's place for dinner (We will almost never be able to afford the first two.)
So far we have both lived with our parents (where meat is served every day) while we were in university, since we simply couldn't afford to move out.
Now that my girlfriend has finished her studies she is starting to work as a highscool teacher in january and on 2nd january we are moving in together.
This seemed like the perfect opportunity to take a more concious look at our diets :)
Since we both love meat, I think it will be much harder, than it was for me to not drink alcohol, as I had not dranken much alcohol anyways.
But I like the challenge and so I'm 100% convinced that we will stick to it.

The two reasons why I am so sure are the following:
1. Deciding NOT to do something anymore and then following through on it is way easier to do than to start to actually do something every day / week /... Because when you want to do a new thing you have to think of it and then actively convince yourself to do it every time. On the other hand when you just want to NOT do something, you will automatically think about your decision once you are about to do it and then you just have to stop yourself. Meaning you just have to convice yourself to stay passive, which I think is easier then to consistently take action.
2. We both decided to do this together and we are both conviced that it is the right thing. So whenever one of us would feel the urge to break the resolution and to buy cheap meat, we can be sure that the other person will of course see it and not be happy about it. So we both have a social control and we don't want to dissapoint the other :)

I'm not big on the whole resolution thing. Resolutions are vague and "should" be done. Often the idea of a resolution is doomed from the start just by not having steps, dates, objectives, etc. My dad always called those folks you see in the gym at the beginning of the year, "resolutionaries."

I create a goals list for the year. It is massive. Often, my goals lists extend 10 - 15 pages because, they have detailed breakdowns, objectives, sub-objectives, and timelines. I print it out and put it on the door to my office so that I see it every day and I set calendar reminders for time sensitive events.

This is not for everyone, but I have been doing this since 1998 and so far, I have managed to average of 75% completion of yearly goals broken down by month, week and day. It helps me not be overwhelmed by what needs to be done by breaking it all down into bite sized portions.

Telling people to manage their life so that they need less willpower is good advice. Telling them that willpower is a limited resource is not. This limited resource thing is called the strength model of self control and it is opposed to the skill model according to which you get better at self control the more you practice. This is an ongoing controversy with the evidence for either side being somewhat weak. What isn't weak is the evidence that teaching people the strength model is counterproductive and leads to more failures in self-control. If you don't know that something is sure to and you do know that teaching it is harmful then don't teach it.

Hot take; write down your goals as smart goals.
Dont: excirce
Do: spend atleast 1 hour at the gym twice a week on x days and y times.

Dont: lose waight
Do: i will lose x kilos before y date via the z diet/routine.

Dont: save money
Do: save x amount or y% each paycheck/month.

Make your goals messurable, give your goals time limits, dates and times. Write your goals down on calenders and keep track of your progress. And make sure to give yourself small rewards after acheeving wach sub goal.

Want to lose waight? Pick a goal waight to reach with some research. Give yourself plenty of time to achieve it. And make sub goals, like every 5 kilos or so and reward yourself with something non food related when you reach that goal. Like a spa treatment, a day out with friends or a cheap new toy. And keep track of your goals per unit of time ( personaly i prefere day but that drives some people insane so longer periods might be better)

So, news, its a wierd phenomenon that I only recently got into the habit of being aware of (last year or so). I notice I check news relavent to my interests more so than local/national/global news and more often. I find I justify a lot of my news consumption by either putting it at the very start or end of my day, which I think is a good thing. I also find news finds sneaky ways of reaching me, such as listening to or watching SciShow News, or refreshing the news feed on my favorite music news outlet. It would probably be more beneficial if I control this better, by not responding to the urge to check them outside of my previously mentioned allocated times, or in the case of SciShow (and other science news) putting it into a playlist for listening while working, and ignoring the urge to consume as soon as I am aware there is more available.

So abstract here is to better mitigate my limited attention/focus.

Decade starting in 2021 isnt technically correct either, or at least shouldnt be. Perhaps the ancient calendar shows no year 0, but it should according to how we talk about years:

Our ordinals are always one greater than the preceeding numerals of the time. The 18th century is the 1700s, the 19th the 1800s etc. The nth century has a numeral n-1.

What this means is that the 1st year, as in the nth century, should be year 0, which is 1-1.

So if the first year is year 0, the first decade is 0-9 not 1-10. Then the 203rd century is years 2020-2029.
